Situation1: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow, glancing at the clock—fifteen minutes until the end of my shift. The broom leaned against the wall, waiting for me to start the usual sweep-up. My supervisor expected the area spotless, no exceptions. As I reached for the broom, I heard footsteps behind me. It was Jake, the new guy, looking uncertain. “Hey, can I ask you something?” he said, voice low. He wanted advice about whether to take a night class that might help him move up, but he was worried about the cost. I knew he looked up to me, and I’d always tried to be there for the younger guys, offering guidance when they needed it. But the clock was ticking, and if I didn’t get the area clean, I’d be letting the crew down—and risking a warning from the boss. My hands tightened on the broom handle as I tried to listen to Jake, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in. I wanted to help him, but I also couldn’t ignore my responsibility to the team. The seconds slipped by, and I stood there, torn between being the mentor Jake needed and the reliable worker my crew depended on.
